The pandemic further strained health-care services, exacerbating mental health issues and homelessness, contributing to a perception of rampant open-air drug use in cities like Portland, observed Marisa Zapata of Portland State University’s Homelessness Research and Action Collaborative.

Advertisement

Despite thousands of citations issued by police, the treatment hotline intended for those cited for drug possession received fewer than 300 calls since the law's inception, according to the health authority.

“Even as it destroys your life, fentanyl use feels so good in the short term that many people won’t try to give it up without the external pressure that Measure 110 eliminated,” said Keith Humphreys, a Stanford University psychiatry professor and former White House drug-policy adviser.

Looking ahead

Public perception linking Measure 110 to spikes in petty crime and open-air drug use has fueled calls for its repeal in several Oregon counties.

Under the legislation passed by the House yesterday, drug possession will revert to a misdemeanor offense, accompanied by penalties of up to 180 days in jail or 18 months of probation. Additionally, the bill encourages diversion to state-funded “deflection” programs aimed at steering individuals toward treatment rather than incarceration. The state is also allocating grants for medication-assisted opioid addiction treatment within jails, among other provisions aimed at addressing addiction.

Advertisement

Officials estimate that the law will result in approximately 2,257 misdemeanor drug possession convictions annually in Oregon, with Black and Hispanic defendants disproportionately represented.

Read David’s full report here.

On the Hill

👀 Government shutdown watch

Congress passed legislation yesterday to keep the government’s lights on this weekend, teeing up another mad scramble over policy and spending negotiations with another shutdown deadline only about a week away, our colleague Jacob Bogage reports.

The stopgap spending bill cleared the Senate by a 77-13 vote last night after winning House approval by a 320-99 margin in the afternoon. The measure now heads to Biden’s desk for his signature.

A closer look: Without the short-term extender, financing for about 20 percent of the government was set to expire Saturday just after midnight.

Advertisement

The legislation pushes the funding deadline for those agencies, including the Food and Drug Administration, to March 8. Funding for the rest of the federal government under the bill expires March 22, two weeks later than under current law.

Reproductive wars

Alabama lawmakers pass legislation to protect IVF treatment

Alabama’s Republican-controlled legislature voted yesterday to protect IVF providers from criminal or civil liability if embryos they help to create are subsequently damaged or destroyed, The Post’s Molly Hennessy-Fiske reports.

The fast action by both the Alabama House and Senate on bills to shield IVF came less than two weeks after the state’s supreme court ruled that frozen embryos are people and that individuals could be liable for destroying them. Within days, nearly every clinic in the state either suspended IVF or halted embryo disposal .

Advertisement

The legislation is soon expected to go to Republican Gov. Kay Ivey, who has voiced support for ensuring that IVF treatment can continue in Alabama.

Meanwhile, in Missouri …

Republican Attorney General Andrew Bailey sued a Planned Parenthood affiliate yesterday, accusing the organization of helping minors travel out of state to obtain abortions without parental consent in violation of Missouri law.

In the lawsuit , Bailey cites undercover footage released by the conservative group Project Veritas last year that purports to show a Planned Parenthood Great Plains employee offering to arrange an abortion for a 13-year-old in Kansas without notifying her parents.

Bailey is seeking a court injunction prohibiting the organization, which operates clinics in Kansas, Missouri, Arkansas and Oklahoma, from helping minors terminate their pregnancies.

The view from Planned Parenthood: A spokesperson for the organization said the Project Veritas video was taken without staff’s knowledge and was “heavily doctored and edited.” They said Planned Parenthood Great Plains does not provide any transportation directly to patients, regardless of age or where they live, Anna Spoerre reports for the Missouri Independent.

Industry Rx

Disruptions from Change Healthcare cyberattack aren’t going away anytime soon

Outages stemming from the cyberattack on UnitedHealth Group’s technology unit may persist for weeks , leaving hospitals and pharmacies to grapple with cumbersome workarounds, Stat’s Brittany Trang reports.

Advertisement

Key context: The insurance giant became aware of the attack against Change Healthcare last Wednesday, prompting a shutdown of its systems to safeguard patient data. More than a week later, the hack continues to disrupt billing and care-authorization portals nationwide, leading to delays in patients’ prescriptions and providers’ paychecks.

To alleviate frustrations, UnitedHealth is launching a loan program to assist providers unable to submit insurance claims while Change remains offline, the company’s chief operating officer, Dirk McMahon, said in a Tuesday conference call with hospital cybersecurity officers. The initiative will last “for the next couple of weeks as this continues to go on,” he said.

Administered through UnitedHealth’s Optum Pay, the program will disburse weekly amounts to providers based on their claim history in the last year. The company would expect providers to pay it back after Change resumes normal operations.

From our reporters' notebooks

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has done its share of policing mortgage brokers, student loan companies and banks. But as the U.S. health-care system turns tens of millions of Americans into debtors, director Rohit Chopra has steered this financial watchdog to the aid of beleaguered patients — adding hospitals, nursing homes and patient financing companies to the list of institutions that regulators have their eyes on.

Advertisement

KFF Health News’ Noam N. Levey is out this morning with an interview with Chopra on the effort. Check it out here .

In other health news

An LGBTQ+ nonprofit is suing Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R) after he demanded the group turn over all records related to its work with families of young people seeking gender-affirming care, The Post’s María Luisa Paúl reports. after he demanded the group turn over all records related to its work with families of young people seeking gender-affirming care, The Post’sreports.

Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee are seeking information from the federal health department on the steps it has taken or will take to ensure that the influx of migrants in certain communities isn’t inhibiting U.S. patients' access to care. on the steps it has taken or will take to ensure that the influx of migrants in certain communities isn’t inhibiting U.S. patients' access to care.

Vaccines this season have so far been 42 percent effective in Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday. in protecting adults against influenza hospitalization, which is on par with recent years, thesaid yesterday.

Quote of the week

“If that’s what it takes to get this done, then let’s do it. But this ‘kicking the can down the road’ crap really does need to stop .” — Sen. Jon Tester (Mont.), on extending funding deadlines again to prevent a partial government shutdown.

Health reads

Sugar rush

title: Biden and Trump head to the border for dueling visits Thursday
short_description: Biden and Trump head to the border for dueling visits Thursday  The Washington Post
text:
President Biden and former president Donald Trump are both traveling to Texas border towns on Thursday, creating an unusual spectacle of dueling visits in which the prospective 2024 presidential rivals are expected to vociferously blame each other for chaos at the border. Cut through the 2024 election noise. Get The Campaign Moment newsletter. ArrowRight Biden will visit Brownsville, making his second trip to the border since becoming president. His trip is part of a recent effort to take the initiative on the issue of illegal immigration, which polls suggest has been politically damaging for him.

Trump, the leading Republican presidential contender, will visit Eagle Pass, a city that has become a symbol of Republican defiance against Biden’s handling of immigration. Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, seized a park in the city earlier this year, shutting out U.S. Border Patrol agents who had long used it as a staging point.

Biden’s visit underscores his political vulnerability after enduring sustained Republican attacks over record levels of migrants at the border. Biden recently embraced a tough bipartisan Senate proposal on immigration, saying he would use its provisions to shut down the border if crossings reached a certain level.

Advertisement

Republicans, who had demanded that border enforcement measures be added to a foreign aid package, blocked the measure after opposition from Trump, who said he feared its passage would help Biden address a political liability.

Frustrated by Congress’s inaction, Biden has been considering executive actions that could limit unauthorized migration and restrict the asylum process, according to administration officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal deliberations.

It is not clear if Biden’s border visit — along with his potential executive actions and newly fiery rhetoric — can change the political dynamic on immigration. But the White House hopes a tougher stance can at a minimum blunt Republicans’ advantage on the issue.

A White House official said Biden on Thursday will “discuss the urgent need to pass the Senate bipartisan border security agreement” and “reiterate his calls for congressional Republicans to stop playing politics and to provide the funding needed for additional U.S. Border Patrol agents, more asylum officers” and other resources.

Advertisement

play Play now NaN min Follow on Podcast episode Spotify Apple Google Amazon

The president also will meet Thursday with Border Patrol agents, law enforcement officials and local political leaders, the official said. The Senate border compromise would have funded the hiring of thousands of Border Patrol and asylum officers, as well as increased detention capacity.

Trump and other Republicans have made it clear they will resist any effort by Biden to deflect the political damage caused by periodic scenes of chaos at the border over the past three years.

In a statement Monday, Trump campaign spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt attacked Biden for his border visit, saying he “had three years to visit the border and fix the crisis he created” and suggesting that the president was only traveling there for political reasons.

“Now Biden’s handlers are sending him there on the same day as President Trump’s publicly reported trip, not because they actually want to solve the problem, but because they know Biden is losing terribly,” Leavitt said. “Biden’s last-minute, insincere attempt to chase President Trump to the border won’t cut it — Americans know Biden is single-handedly responsible for the worst immigration crisis in history and the ensuing Biden Migrant Crime Crisis affecting every community in our Country.”

Advertisement

The president’s actions, less than a month after he said he had “done all I can do” to secure the border unilaterally, reflect how the surge in migration continues to vex his administration. Biden in recent weeks has signaled a new willingness to take aggressive actions that have long been anathema to many Democrats.

Administration officials said last week that no final decisions had been made on possible executive actions and that it remained possible that Biden ultimately would not take such measures.

In December, record numbers of migrants surged to the border, though illegal border crossings have fallen 50 percent since then.

Trump, who attracted support for his first presidential run in 2016 in part with his harsh rhetoric on immigration, including a promise to build a border wall, is seeking to put the issue at the center of his current campaign as well.

Advertisement

The former president often has used dehumanizing language to describe undocumented immigrants, suggesting they have launched an “invasion” of the United States and accusing them of “poisoning the blood of the country,” language that has drawn comparisons with Nazi rhetoric.

Trump has taken credit for killing the Senate border compromise, which was hammered out by a bipartisan group of senators over a period of weeks. GOP lawmakers abandoned the deal after Trump said that such a measure “would be another Gift to the Radical Left Democrats.”

Polls show a majority of voters are unhappy with Biden’s handling of border issues.

A Monmouth University poll this month found that 71 percent of Americans disapproved of Biden’s handling of immigration and 26 percent approved. Disapproval of the president’s handling of immigration was 13 points higher than disapproval of his overall job performance, which is at 58 percent.

Advertisement

The same poll found 61 percent saying illegal immigration is a “very serious problem,” up from 46 percent in 2019 and 45 percent in 2015. While concern about the issue varies sharply by party, the level of concern was up among Democrats, Republicans and independents.

Biden, who at a fundraiser last week said the “border is in chaos,” has continued to hammer Republicans for tanking the bipartisan legislation, which would have provided more funding for border enforcement and given the president new authority to restrict migration.

The White House has touted the conservative Border Patrol union’s support for the bill and has continued to call on Republicans to pass the legislation, though its prospects seem dim. Without the benefit of additional funding in the legislation, White House aides say any executive order by Biden would have limited impact.

Advertisement

“Congressional Republicans chose to put partisan politics ahead of our national security, rejected what border agents have said they need, and then gave themselves a two-week vacation,” White House spokesman Angelo Fernández Hernández said in a statement Thursday, referring to a recent congressional recess.

“No executive action, no matter how aggressive, can deliver the significant policy reforms and additional resources Congress can provide and that Republicans rejected,” he added.

At the same time, Biden is facing pressure from progressives in his party unhappy about his apparent shift to the right on immigration.

“Doing Trump impressions isn’t how we beat Trump,” Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) posted last week on X, formerly known as Twitter, pointing to reports that Biden planned to use powers championed by Trump to block migrants from entering the country. “Seeking asylum is a legal right of all people. In the face of authoritarian threat, we should not buckle on our principles — we should commit to them.”

Advertisement

Trump, however, continued his onslaught against both Biden and undocumented immigrants.

“When I am your President, we will immediately Seal the Border, Stop the Invasion, and on Day One, we will begin the largest deportation operation of illegal CRIMINALS in American History!” he posted on Truth Social.

In that post, Trump referenced the recent killing of Laken Hope Riley, an Augusta University nursing student whose body was found on the University of Georgia campus. Jose Ibarra, who crossed the border illegally, has been taken into custody.

“Crooked Joe Biden’s INVASION is destroying our country and killing our citizens!” Trump wrote. “The horrible murder of 22-year-old Laken Riley at the University of Georgia should have NEVER happened!”

A U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement spokesperson said Ibarra was arrested in September 2022 “after unlawfully entering the United States near El Paso, Texas,” and was “paroled and released for further processing.”

title: Mike Johnson is again staring down a government shutdown — and his conference
short_description: Mike Johnson again faces a government shutdown, split Republican conference  The Washington Post
text:
The House returned to Washington on Wednesday with the goal of averting a partial government shutdown — a looming deadline that has become routine in the past several months as the notoriously fractious House Republican conference has fought against a Democratic Senate and the White House. Cut through the 2024 election noise. Get The Campaign Moment newsletter. ArrowRight Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.), the conference’s nascent leader who has spent the past four months learning on the job while being pulled by opposite poles in his party, is once again days away from a government shutdown and staring down competing demands from his members. The conference is split almost down the middle on two pressing issues that Senate leaders and President Biden largely agree on: how to fund the government and sending aid to foreign democracies, particularly Ukraine.

As he faces two government shutdown deadlines over the next 10 days and pressure from all corners to aid Ukraine, Johnson has to weigh warring factors to either find consensus with bipartisan Senate leaders and the White House or cave to the far-right’s wishes to walk away from negotiations. The former could cost him his job.

Advertisement

But the lack of unity among House Republicans, whose first year in the majority was defined by their inability to agree on must-address issues, has weakened Johnson’s hand as he negotiates without a cohesive message on conservative demands. And many GOP lawmakers and aides said Johnson’s thinking is further complicated as he struggles to marry his own hard-line conservative ideology with his desire to govern.

Johnson has agreed with appropriators and other congressional leaders that they need to buy more time to pass funding bills through each chamber, proposing to Democrats late Tuesday the option to extend Friday’s deadline by a week and the March 8 deadline by two weeks, according to two people familiar with the offer. The deal, which the four congressional leaders and top appropriators agreed to Wednesday, is contingent on passing half of the 12 appropriations bills by next week, allowing for more time to work through more controversial funding legislation as Johnson aims to ensure this is the last short-term funding extension. The House is expected to vote on the stopgap measure on Thursday.

While Republican lawmakers acknowledge the unworkable position Johnson is in, concerns about Johnson’s “listen, then decide” approach have also amplified over the past month, leaving the conference feeling united in at least one thing: its disillusionment about a path forward.

Advertisement

“I have no confidence this ends well for House GOP,” said one House Republican, who, like others, spoke on the condition of anonymity to speak candidly about feelings within the conference.

The speaker’s allies argue that Johnson was put in an impossible position to lead a divided conference — a job he sought — and that the conference should unite behind him to strengthen his hands in negotiations. Johnson himself has been open publicly and in closed-door meetings with Republicans that there is only so much their two-seat majority can do if they remain fractured.

Complicating Johnson’s fate are the taunts from some lawmakers who have floated ousting him from the speakership — a move that would descend the House into further chaos, as it did last year when Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) was removed. Detractors have decried another possible stopgap measure — the third in four months — that would extend current funding levels while giving appropriators more time to finish fiscal year funding bills, even though the group has contributed to the delay by moving the goal posts on their demands. They also are vehemently opposed to putting a Ukraine funding bill on the floor for a vote.

Members of the House Freedom Caucus also are angry with Johnson for trying to sell the previous stopgap measure as necessary to negotiate a number of conservative funding wins, only to tell lawmakers in a call last week to lower their expectations.

Advertisement

“I don’t think anybody on this call thinks that we’re going to be able to use the appropriations process to fundamentally remake major areas of policy,” Johnson told members on a Friday call, according to multiple people familiar with his comments. “If you’re expecting a lot of home runs and grand slams here, I admit you’ll be disappointed.”

Several Freedom Caucus members were critical for what they claimed was Johnson moving the goal post. After meeting with Johnson on Wednesday evening, Rep. Bob Good (R-Va.), who chairs the group, said he would vote against the stopgap measure and hoped the speaker wouldn’t bring a bill to the floor that does not have a majority of Republican support.

Freedom Caucus members are instead pushing Johnson to pass an extension of current funding levels until Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year — a plan they initially were against — which would trigger a 7 to 10 percent cut in nondefense discretionary spending based on parameters agreed to by Biden and McCarthy in last year’s debt ceiling deal. But if lawmakers continue to use temporary funding extensions beyond April 30, that would instead trigger a 1 percent cut of current funding, which would include defense, veterans, Pell grants and other priorities that Democrats and Republicans — particularly defense hawks — are eager to avoid.

Advertisement

Freedom Caucus members have also made other demands. In a letter sent to the speaker last week, they listed almost two dozen requests they would want to see addressed in appropriation bills that would sour support for approval in the Senate. They included reducing Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas’s salary to $0, defunding Planned Parenthood, ending “radical” climate change initiatives by the Biden administration and other culture war measures.

Pragmatic lawmakers have urged Johnson to ignore the demands of the far right, arguing that they are likely to still vote against any proposal Johnson makes because it isn’t conservative enough. The latter perspective paired with a razor-thin majority has forced GOP leadership to rely on Democratic votes to pass legislation, which further irritates the far-right flank.

In a floor speech Monday, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said that a shutdown “is entirely avoidable” and urged House Republicans to give up on culture war demands.

Advertisement

“I’ll say at the outset what I’ve said every time Congress has faced this threat: Shutting down the government is harmful to the country. And it never produces positive outcomes — on policy or politics,” McConnell said. “As always, the task at hand will require that everyone rows in the same direction: toward clean appropriations and away from poison pills.”

House Speaker Mike Johnson, Sen. Charles E. Schumer, and Rep. Hakeem Jeffries discuss top congressional priorities after meeting with President Biden on Feb. 27 (Video: Billy Tucker/The Washington Post)

In a meeting with Biden on Tuesday, top Democratic leaders and Johnson all expressed optimism that the first four funding bills could broker a compromise soon. House Republicans are largely in agreement to avoid a government shutdown where many know their party would get blamed for being unable to govern, especially ahead of consequential primaries Tuesday.

But the fissures between House Republicans’ persistent demand to include border security in any Ukraine funding bill led to what was described by congressional leaders as an “intense” and “honest” meeting with Biden. Johnson said his purpose in the meeting, with leaders and then separately with Biden, was “to express what I believe is the obvious truth, and that is that we must take care of America’s needs first.” He added that he was “clear with the president and all those in the room that the House is actively pursuing and investigating all the various options” to fund Ukraine but that fixing the border remains the priority.

Advertisement

According to multiple people familiar with the meeting, Biden and the congressional leaders hammered Johnson for not prioritizing aiding Ukraine in its war against Russia. One of those people said Johnson told leaders that it wasn’t helpful to gang up on him for expressing a dominant opinion among his conference and that exerting more pressure on him to cave wouldn’t garner a different outcome.

“I think Speaker Johnson has a decision to make. Is he going to go down in history as Neville Chamberlain, or is he going to write his own story?” said Sen. Chris Murphy (Conn.), the Democrat who brokered the Senate bipartisan border deal. “So he just has to make a decision if he wants to hand deliver Ukraine to [Russian President] Vladimir Putin as the lead story on his political obituary.”

Schumer said that after the meeting that Johnson wants to find a way to fund Ukraine but that he also “made it clear he’s in a difficult position in a caucus with a margin of two.” McConnell, who Democratic leaders said was animated in his defense of Ukraine even though Republicans in his conference are split on the issue, said his hope was that the House would consider the Senate supplemental funding bill aiding foreign democracies, warning that any changes made to it would result only in “further delays.”

“Not only do we not want to shut the government down, but we don’t want the Russians to win in Ukraine. And so, we have a time problem here,” McConnell said at his weekly news conference Tuesday. “The best way to move quickly and get the bill to the president is for the House to take up the Senate bill and pass it.”

title: Supreme Court revives debate over social media as a ‘public square’
short_description: Analysis | Supreme Court revives debate over social media as a 'public square'  The Washington Post
text:
Happy Wednesday! I’m just trying to stay a step ahead of “uncommitted.” Send news tips to: will.oremus@washpost.com.



Below: President Biden issues an executive order on data security. First: The Supreme Court revives debate over whether social media is a ‘public square’ Wp Get the full experience. Choose your plan ArrowRight Reviewing the constitutionality of Florida and Texas laws that would restrict how online platforms can moderate users’ speech, the Supreme Court on Monday revived a long-standing debate: whether social media has become the new “public square.”

The court ruled long ago that states can’t intervene in the editorial decisions of newspapers to promote political balance. But attorneys for Florida and Texas argued on Monday that tech platforms are fundamentally different from newspapers. As forums that represent themselves as being open to the public, sites like Facebook, YouTube, TikTok and X can be held to standards of neutrality and non-discrimination in the name of upholding users’ speech rights, they argued.

Advertisement

At least a few justices seemed sympathetic to the argument.

“I think we agree that the government couldn’t make editorial judgments about who can speak and what they can say in the public square,” Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson said. “But what do you do with the fact that now, today, the Internet is the public square? And I appreciate that these companies are private companies, but if the speech now is occurring in this environment, why wouldn’t the same concerns about censorship apply?”

At various points, justices Neil M. Gorsuch, Samuel A. Alito and Clarence Thomas also signaled interest in the idea. Gorsuch suggested that social platforms present themselves as “open to all comers,” making them more like a telegraph than a newspaper.

But the public square analogy could also cut the other way.

Advertisement

Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. acknowledged Texas and Florida’s concern about the “market power and ability of social media platforms to control” online speech. But he expressed skepticism about the idea of substituting the “power of the state” for those private companies’ power.

“I wonder, since we’re talking about the First Amendment, whether our first concern should be with the state regulating what we have called the modern public square?” Roberts said. In other words, if online platforms have become so essential to free speech, that could be all the more reason for the government to be wary of intervening in their policies.

The question of social platforms’ market power came up repeatedly.

If a site like Facebook has become an essential communications tool, thanks to its vast scale, then excluding users from it could start to look more like censorship than editorial judgment. While the Texas and Florida laws were motivated by Republicans’ frustrations with Big Tech, some left-leaning groups also worry that online platforms have grown too powerful to be granted a First Amendment right to discriminate among viewpoints.

Advertisement

“These are the public squares, the only difference is they’re privately owned,” says Lee Hepner, legal counsel at the nonprofit American Economic Liberties Project. “And just because they’re privately owned does not mean they can discriminate and censor speech based on viewpoint.” He pointed to the court’s 1980 ruling in PruneYard v. Robins that a venue can be a public square for speech purposes even if it’s privately owned, as in the case of a shopping mall.

But today’s tumultuous social media landscape may make it harder to argue that any given platform is a public square unto itself.

Justice Elena Kagan pointed to the changes Elon Musk has wrought at Twitter, now called X, to highlight how different platforms create different environments for speech. “Twitter users one day woke up and found themselves to be X users, and the content rules had changed, and their feeds changed,” she said. “And all of a sudden they were getting a different online newspaper, so to speak, in a metaphorical sense every morning.”

Advertisement

In reaction, rival platforms for text-based feeds such as Meta’s Threads and Bluesky sprang up, with their own distinctive speech policies. Meanwhile, Facebook’s hold on the public sphere arguably has been eroded by the rise of TikTok and its emergence as a force in politics and culture. It’s a point Roberts alluded to when he called social media “an incredibly dynamic market.”

NetChoice attorney Paul Clement said it would be one thing if Facebook could limit your access to the wider internet, like a cable company. But it doesn’t have that power. “There’s always a way to access the public square,” he said.

In other words, the true digital public square is not Facebook, YouTube or X, but the internet as a whole.

Mary Anne Franks, a First Amendment scholar at George Washington University Law School, says there are “many reasons to be concerned about the way that social media dominates people’s lives.” But she said that “the answer to those concerns is not to treat private companies as if they were governments.”

Advertisement

“A private square remains a private square no matter how popular it gets,” she said. “And, as we have seen in the last few years, there is not one private square, but a growing variety of private squares that people can migrate to and from or abandon altogether.”

As Justice Sonia Sotomayor put it: “The one thing I know about the internet is that its variety is infinite.”

Our top tabs

Biden issues order blocking bulk sale of DNA, location data to foreign buyers

President Biden on Wednesday issued an executive order designed to block the bulk transfer of Americans’ most sensitive data to buyers in China and other “countries of concern,” my colleague Drew Harwell reports for The Tech 202.

The order, which the White House called “the most significant executive action any President has ever taken to protect Americans’ data security,” directs the Justice Department to establish clear protections for biometric, financial, genomic, geolocation and health data, some of which is legally sold by commercial data brokers. The process has for years fueled concern that the personal information could be collected by foreign governments or militaries for use in blackmail or espionage.



Harwell and Ellen Nakashima previously broke news of the impending order here.

Inside the industry

Advertisement

Competition watch

Privacy monitor

Workforce report

Trending

Daybook

Before you log off

Police were called to an 'immersive' Willy Wonka Experience after families showed up to an 'empty warehouse'



The event reportedly charged $40 for entry, advertised with AI art, and said it would be a 'journey filled with wondrous creations and enchanting surprises at every… pic.twitter.com/udz8KeWVxQ — Culture Crave 🍿 (@CultureCrave) February 27, 2024

title: The Supreme Court confronts a public health challenge: Homeless encampments
short_description: Analysis | The Supreme Court confronts a public health challenge: Homeless encampments  The Washington Post
text:
Good morning. I’m Angela Hart, senior correspondent at KFF Health News in Sacramento, where I keep an eye on Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom, his health policies — and his ambitions. Send tips on under-covered health or homelessness issues to AngelaH@kff.org . Not a subscriber? Sign up here . Wp Get the full experience. Choose your plan ArrowRight Today’s edition: Senate Democrats are trying to fast-track federal protections for fertility treatments. Federal antitrust authorities have launched an investigation into the nation’s biggest health insurer. But first …

Competing public health concerns are at the heart of a Supreme Court case on homeless encampments

Homelessness is a soaring public health crisis, with a record 653,000 unhoused people in the United States, according to federal estimates . Tent and recreational vehicle encampments have exploded in recent years, crowding streets and sidewalks from Portland, Ore., to New York . In California, where roughly a third of all the nation’s homeless people live, doctors are scheduling appointments at encampments to treat widespread chronic disease, rampant drug abuse and mental illness — health conditions that worsen with homelessness.

Advertisement

In April, the U.S. Supreme Court will delve into an issue central to the plight of those living in homeless encampments: whether they can be fined or slapped with criminal charges for living or sleeping outdoors when there’s no shelter or housing available.

The situation on the streets is causing major political upheaval. In California, Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) is plowing $750 million into clearing encampments — with the elusive promise of shelter — while homeless advocates fight to stop it. But it’s a small city in Oregon called Grants Pass that took the battle to the Supreme Court.

City of Grants Pass v. Johnson centers on whether it’s cruel and unusual punishment to impose fines and criminal citations for camping or sleeping outside, which is against the law in many cities. Some homeless advocates fear the court’s conservative majority will give carte blanche to state and local officials to sweep encampments in the name of public health and safety.

Advertisement

Newsom is asking California voters to approve a $6.4 billion bond to create thousands of new homeless housing units and behavioral health treatment beds to get people off the streets. But he argued in an amicus brief that clearing encampments should be allowed and that it can help provide services to unhoused people living in “inhumane conditions,” he said. “The courts have tied the hands of state and local governments.”

He and other public officials also argue that encampments harm public health; a 2016-2018 outbreak of hepatitis A in San Diego linked to homelessness resulted in nearly 600 infections and 20 deaths .

Yet a growing body of evidence suggests sweeps can worsen the health of people in encampments while causing turmoil in their lives and for the people trying to care for them — potentially costing taxpayer-funded Medicaid programs even more money.

Advertisement

A study published last year in JAMA also found that displacing homeless people from encampments can lead to higher hospitalizations — raising health-care costs — and cause serious infections and early death.

“Sweeps prolong homelessness — you can make them disappear from this corner or that corner, but they’re just going to appear somewhere else,” said Eric Tars, senior policy director for the National Homelessness Law Center. “If you want to follow public health approaches, what we need to be doing is getting more people into housing, which evidence shows improves health.”

Sweeps also hurt fragile relationships between homeless people and their caregivers.

“A lot of people on the streets with mental illness live with the fear that anyone who’s trying to help them might get them hospitalized against their will or put in jail,” said Hannah Wesolowski, chief advocacy officer for the National Alliance on Mental Illness . “So when encampments are being cleared by law enforcement, it totally upends people’s lives and violates that trust in a way that they’re going to be more resistant to help.”

Advertisement

But with housed Americans in both parties clamoring for their streets to be safer and cleaner, the health concerns of homeless people aren’t always a priority for politicians.

KFF Health News is a national newsroom that produces in-depth journalism about health issues and is one of the core operating programs at KFF — an independent source of health policy research, polling and journalism.

Reproductive Wars

Senate Democrats look to put Republicans on IVF defense

On tap today: On Capitol Hill, a group of Senate Democrats will try to force a vote on a bill aimed at codifying access to in vitro fertilization (IVF) and other fertility treatments in the wake of the Alabama Supreme Court ruling that frozen embryos are people .

Sen. Tammy Duckworth (D-Ill.), who conceived both her daughters through IVF, plans to call on her colleagues to pass her Access to Family Building Act through unanimous consent. She attempted the same maneuver in 2022, but Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith (R-Miss.) swiftly blocked it .

Advertisement

Reality check: Senate conservative are likely to once again scuttle the vote. But for Democrats the procedural move is a chance to put Republicans’ opposition to federal protections for fertility treatments on the record, further elevating the issue as election season intensifies.

Sen. Tammy Duckworth (D-Ill.):

Without the miracle of IVF, I likely wouldn't have my two beautiful girls—and I know I'm not alone.



Tomorrow, I will head to the floor and call on my colleagues to pass my legislation through unanimous consent so we can protect access to IVF nationwide. pic.twitter.com/OTeU93GFQT — Tammy Duckworth (@SenDuckworth) February 27, 2024

Meanwhile, across the Capitol …

Rep. Nancy Mace (R-S.C.) is circulating a nonbinding resolution to House members in both parties expressing “strong support for continued access to fertility care,” Axios’s Andrew Solender reports.

According to Mace, the five-page measure is meant to “build consensus” as she prepares IVF-related legislation.

And in Alabama …

Republican lawmakers in Alabama introduced a pair of companion bills yesterday that would shield IVF providers from both criminal charges and civil lawsuits, the Alabama Reflector’s Jemma Stephenson reports.

Advertisement

The proposed legislation doesn’t attempt to define the point at which human life begins, after bill sponsors scrapped draft language that referred to embryos as “potential life” unless implanted in the uterus.

Next steps: Lawmakers are aiming to fast-track the bills through the state Senate and House within five days, the minimum time frame required to send legislation to Republican Gov. Kay Ivey’s desk for consideration.

Alabama House Speaker Nathaniel Ledbetter (R):

Thank you, Coach!



House and Senate leadership are committed to protecting IVF in the state of Alabama. https://t.co/k7p0kDwGOH — Nathaniel Ledbetter (@RepLedbetter) February 23, 2024

Agency alert

Federal antitrust authorities take aim at UnitedHealth Group

The Biden administration has initiated an antitrust probe into the nation’s largest health insurer, Anna Wilde Mathews and Dave Michaels report for the Wall Street Journal.

The details: Justice Department investigators have been actively interviewing industry insiders in recent weeks, particularly those in sectors where UnitedHealth Group competes, according to people familiar with the matter.

Advertisement

The conversations have included questions about the relationship between the company’s insurance unit and its health services arm, Optum .

Additionally, investigators have asked about the effects of UnitedHealth's extensive acquisitions of doctor groups on both competitors and consumers.

Key context: This isn’t the first time the insurance giant has faced scrutiny from federal antitrust authorities. In September 2022, UnitedHealth successfully defeated a challenge mounted by the Justice Department over its acquisition of Change Healthcare.

State Scan

Anesthesia practices move to settle Colorado allegations

One of the largest anesthesia practices in the nation will give up exclusive contracts at five hospitals to settle allegations by the state’s attorney general’s office that it engaged in anti-competitive practices and drove prices up 30 percent over other firms, The Post’s Peter Whoriskey reports.

U.S. Anesthesia Partners will also revise employment contracts that previously hindered its physicians from working at other practices. The company and its private equity founder, Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, continue to deny any unlawful conduct.

Advertisement

Why it matters: The growing role of private equity firms in U.S. physician practices has drawn criticism from politicians and watchdogs who say the financiers are enriching investors by monopolizing markets and raising prices.

In other health news

South Dakota voters will be asked this fall whether the state should Jack Dura reports for the Associated Press. whether the state should require certain Medicaid enrollees to work as a condition of their health coverage,reports for

An experimental drug from Viking Therapeutics helped patients shed nearly 15 percent of their body weight over 13 weeks in a mid-stage trial , positioning it as a viable competitor to market leaders like Ozempic and Mounjaro, our colleague Daniel Gilbert reports. , positioning it as a viable competitor to market leaders like Ozempic and Mounjaro, our colleaguereports.

On the move: Rachel Weiss the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services as a senior adviser for external affairs. Weiss, who previously served as vice president of health-care advocacy at Arnold Ventures, will focus on the Inflation Reduction Act and Medicare Advantage. has joined theas a senior adviser for external affairs. Weiss, who previously served as vice president of health-care advocacy at, will focus on the Inflation Reduction Act and Medicare Advantage.
